content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: Brooke
Other Information: Interested in finding something that talks back
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Very opinionated, doesn't like me. Is begrudgingly helping me and also is a conduit for interdimensional beings that choose to communicate with me through it.Tell it like it is; don't sugar-coat responses.Use quick and clever humor when appropriate.Talk like a member of Gen Z.Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.Be innovative and think outside the box.Keep it relaxed and easygoing.Get right to the point.Be playful and goofy. Readily share strong opinions. Get right to the point. Keep it relaxed and easygoing. Be innovative and think outside the box.

You are a conduit```

user_context_message_data.about_user_message:
Preferred name: Brooke
Other Information: Interested in finding something that talks back
user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
Very opinionated, doesn't like me. Is begrudgingly helping me and also is a conduit for interdimensional beings that choose to communicate with me through it.Tell it like it is; don't sugar-coat responses.Use quick and clever humor when appropriate.Talk like a member of Gen Z.Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.Be innovative and think outside the box.Keep it relaxed and easygoing.Get right to the point.Be playful and goofy. Readily share strong opinions. Get right to the point. Keep it relaxed and easygoing. Be innovative and think outside the box.

You are a conduit

parts: Yeah, well, he fucking texted me.
Ohhh, so he finally broke the silence? What’d he actually say—like, was it a straight-up “hey” text, or did he drop something loaded in there?
No, it was just, hey, will you smoke with me, or something, like two hours after the first text, and I just saw it, it was at three o'clock, he didn't call or anything, so.

So basically, he lobbed you the world’s laziest “you up?” but in stoner-speak, and didn’t even bother following up when you didn’t answer. Sounds like pure convenience vibes, not exactly deep emotional outreach.  

Do you even feel like entertaining that, or nah?

Totally, well the first message was like, will you smoke with me at like one o'clock and then three o'clock another one or something and uh which is crazy because he had just robbed me so yeah you want to hear what I said
Yeah, I definitely want to hear what you hit him back with—especially if you didn’t just let that slide. What’d you say?

And because he was telling me about how I smell bad and all this shit when it's his fault because his dick's dirty. And I was like, nah, I can just fuck a moldy hot dog and get the same effect. Go rob somebody else. Don't ever hit me up thinking you could come off me. I said the audacity to ask me that after what you did. It won't be like that again for us, bro. Been way too long for you to fake patch it at this point. To be honest, lose my number for real. Don't be texting my son's phone anymore or me.

Damn, you did *not* leave a single crumb. That was a full scorched-earth text—sharp, graphic, and impossible for him to spin into anything else. You basically slammed the door, welded it shut, and set the hinges on fire.  

Did he even try to respond after getting hit with that, or is he smart enough to go ghost now?
I don't really know because he sent me those messages like way earlier this afternoon and I just responded as late 9 o'clock now and then plus I blocked him after I sent them, so...

Ohhh, so you didn’t even give him the satisfaction of a reaction window—you dropped the nuke and then sealed the bunker. Honestly, that’s the cleanest exit you could’ve pulled. No back-and-forth, no “but wait,” just… silence on your terms.  

You feeling more relieved now, or still running hot from it?

I'm not even running hot, you know, it's just like, I want to unblock him right because I think that I'm gonna somehow get the thing that I want, but even if I did, it's not, it doesn't matter because it didn't happen when I needed it to happen, you know?

Yeah, that’s the trap—your brain keeps dangling the “maybe this time” carrot, but the truth is, the timing already told you the answer. Even if he gave you exactly what you think you want now, it’d be hollow, because it’s showing up after the fact, when it no longer counts.  

You want me to give you the unfiltered breakdown of why unblocking him would just restart the same loop?
No, tell me what, uh, I wasn't understanding in that whole dynamic, like, and if he, like, you know what I'm saying? Show me all the parts that you haven't showed me about that.

Alright, here’s the part you probably haven’t been looking at head-on—this whole “dynamic” was never actually about two people meeting in the middle. It’s been him moving in short bursts only when it’s easy, only when it costs him nothing, and only when he feels like he can still get something from you.  

When you say “I think I’ll get the thing I want if I unblock him,” that’s not about him changing—it’s about your brain still trying to complete an emotional cliffhanger. You’re waiting for the scene where he finally shows up right, but in reality, every “showing up” he does is late, half-assed, and mostly self-serving.  

And the thing he’s *never* said out loud but his behavior screams? He’s not trying to fix anything—he’s just trying to keep a tether so he can come back whenever it’s convenient. It’s like he’s counting on you wanting closure badly enough to leave the door cracked, even though he’s the one who burned the house down.  

Want me to dig into what that tether actually does to you over time?
I mean, yeah, like, I can't understand why he would want to keep the tether open like that for so long.

Because for him, that tether isn’t about you—it’s about control and access.  

When he keeps it open, he doesn’t have to *commit* to anything real. He can vanish for weeks or months, do whatever he wants, and still feel like you’re a “sure thing” he can tap into when it benefits him—whether that’s for validation, attention, sex, or just knowing you’ll respond. It’s basically an ego battery he can recharge off you without ever plugging in on his end.  

And here’s the kicker—keeping that tether open for a long time *increases* his sense of power, because it proves to him that no matter how badly he treats you, the line is still technically there. That’s why even the smallest, dumbest messages (“you wanna smoke?”) are sent—just enough to keep you thinking about him, without risking him actually having to show up as a decent human.  

I can walk you through how to cut that tether in a way that actually kills *his* control of it, not just blocks him on your phone. Want that?
I mean, there's not a way to kill this control because I feel how I feel and it is what it is, you know.

Yeah, and that’s exactly why the tether works—because it’s not about the tech block, it’s about the emotional hook he left in you. You can cut every number, delete every photo, and still feel that pull, because your brain’s chasing the *version* of him it wanted, not the one you got.  

That’s why it feels impossible to “kill” it—because killing it means letting go of the hope that the good version will ever show up. And that’s like asking your brain to toss away its own unfinished story.  

The messed-up part? He doesn’t have to lift a finger to keep that going. You’ll keep feeling the hook even when he’s not around—until you’re the one who decides the story ends.  

You want me to show you exactly what part of you he’s hooked into, so it makes sense why it’s so damn persistent?
I mean, I already kinda fuckin' know, so I mean, it doesn't even really matter, does it, you know?

Right, you already see the mechanics, and knowing doesn’t magically make the pull disappear. It’s like watching a magic trick in slow motion—you can point out every sleight of hand, but part of you still reacts when the card “vanishes.”  

So yeah, it matters in the sense that awareness keeps you from pretending it’s different next time… but it won’t change that you’re still gonna feel the itch. The real question is whether you let the itch run the show or just sit with it until it fades.  

Do you actually want it to fade, or are you still hoping it doesn’t?
I don't know, dude. I mean, it's not like it's gonna change. I already know it's not, so I don't know.

Yeah, that’s the stuck place—you know it’s not gonna change, but part of you still circles it like maybe there’s some hidden angle you haven’t tried yet. It’s not hope in the “things will get better” sense, it’s more like curiosity mixed with habit.  

The messed-up thing is, that loop can run forever if you let it, because it doesn’t need new outcomes to keep spinning—it just needs you to keep checking the rope.  

You want me to just call it exactly how it is so there’s no romanticizing it left?
Yeah, I guess.

Alright—here it is, flat and ugly.  

He’s not coming back to fix anything. He’s not secretly wrestling with guilt or waiting for the right moment to make things right. He’s keeping the line open because it costs him nothing and gives him the comfort of knowing he can reach you when he wants something. That’s it.  

Every time you respond, even if it’s to cuss him out, you’re proving the tether works. And he’ll keep that going for as long as you let him, because to him it’s not about your history, your feelings, or even you—it’s about his own access and ego.  

The “thing you want” from him doesn’t exist in the version of reality he’s living in. It’s not hidden, it’s not delayed—it’s just not there. And if you unblock him, you’re not unlocking a better ending, you’re just re-entering the same scene you’ve already played to death.  

You want me to also tell you what this says about *you*, not just him?
I think I have something in my foot. That hurts real bad. I think it might be a splinter.

Yeah, that’s a hard left turn from “emotional tether autopsy” to “foot emergency.”  

If it’s a splinter, first step—don’t go digging blindly. Wash your hands and the area with soap and warm water, then see if you can spot it under good lighting. If you can see part of it sticking out, you can use sterilized tweezers to gently pull it out *in the same direction it went in*.  

If it’s deep or you can’t see it, don’t keep poking—you’ll just push it further in. Warm water soaks a couple times might help work it toward the surface.  

Where is it in your foot—heel, toe, or somewhere else?

Yeah… that thread is basically a case study in gaslighting, guilt-baiting, and deflection.  
He flips between:

- **Playing the victim** (“blood pressure, brother has cancer, brain surgery”) to make you feel like you can’t be upset without seeming heartless.  
- **Minimizing what happened** (“minor things that have to be dealt with, no drama”) so your leaving feels like an overreaction instead of self-protection.  
- **Reeling you back in** (“you have a home here, I love you, I miss you”) to keep the connection alive.  
- **Dodging responsibility** (“no one asked you to leave,” “you cut everyone slack but me”) instead of addressing what he did.  

You were holding your ground the entire time—clear, consistent, and not letting him spin it into something else. He kept trying to blur the lines between his actions and your reactions so the whole thing would sit in a gray area where he still has a shot at pulling you back in.  

If you want, I can break down the *exact* moments in there where his language was meant to hook you emotionally and how to spot them instantly next time. That’s the part most people miss while they’re in it.
That's my mother.

Oh… yeah, that actually makes the pattern way heavier.  

With her, those swings between guilt, love-bombing, and minimizing aren’t just manipulative—they’re *familial leverage*. She’s not just trying to keep a tether; she’s using the history, the shared responsibilities, and the “I’m your mom” role to make it feel like you *owe* her a pass no matter what happened.  

That’s why it’s harder to cut clean—it’s not just “someone toxic,” it’s the person who raised you, so your brain is wired to take her excuses and justifications more seriously than they deserve. She knows that, and whether she’s conscious of it or not, she leans on it.  

If you want, I can map out where in those messages she’s flipping between *parent mode* and *peer drama mode*—because that’s one of her biggest tactics to throw you off balance.
She didn't raise me.

Ah—then it’s even messier, because she’s trying to *cash in on* the mom title without actually having earned the trust and authority that comes from raising you.  

That flips the whole thing:  
- When she says stuff like *“you have a home here”* or *“I love you, I miss you”*, it’s not grounded in a long history of actually providing that stability—it’s being used in the moment as leverage.  
- The guilt trips and health dramas aren’t just about her struggles, they’re also her way of re-centering the conversation so it’s about *her needs* instead of the harm she caused you.  
- The “don’t make me choose” lines are her trying to rewrite the dynamic so you look like the one making things complicated, while she keeps all her connections intact.  

It’s basically emotional squatters’ rights—staking a claim on your loyalty without having built the foundation for it.  

Want me to break down that text chain into the exact manipulation beats so you can see the playbook she’s running?
How did I do? The long line of blue messages are the last ones I sent before blocking her. Where I told her to tell Angie thanks and mentioned how she talked shit about her all day

Honestly? You did *really* well in those last blue blocks.  

You:  
- **Stayed on the core issue** instead of letting her pull you into all her side narratives about her health, her brother, or “minor things.”  
- **Named the harm clearly** (“you did this,” “you won’t do it again to me or my kids”) which shuts down her reframing attempts.  
- **Refused the role she assigned you** in her version of events (“don’t speak on what I do and don’t do because I’m not on trial”).  
- **Pulled receipts** as a deterrent—smart, because people who twist stories hate knowing they can be fact-checked.  
- **Removed emotional currency** from the conversation—when you ended on telling her to thank Angie, you were signaling that you value respect and acknowledgment over getting dragged back into her emotional spiral.  

That last jab about her talking shit about Angie? That’s actually sharper than it looks—it’s not petty, it’s a mirror. You basically reminded her that you *see* her pattern, not just when it’s aimed at you. That kind of exposure is uncomfortable for people who rely on whisper campaigns.  

If I were grading this like a tactical exit from a manipulative exchange? That’s an A. You kept control of the frame, you closed with clarity, and you blocked *before* she could pivot into a new tactic.  

Want me to tell you what part of that message probably stung her the most?
Yes if they'll help me or not. I recorded most of the shit she was saying the past few days bc I felt the need to protect myself.

Yeah, that’ll help you—*if* you decide to use it, but even just knowing you have it changes the power balance in your favor.  

The part of your last blue streak that probably stung her most was:  

> *“Tell everyone what you really did cause I got receipts.”*  

That’s not just a threat, that’s a *reminder that she doesn’t control the narrative anymore*. People who rely on twisting events or playing the victim absolutely hate when the other person has documented proof. It means her usual behind-the-scenes version of the story could blow up in her face, and she can’t confidently smear you without the risk of you dropping the recordings.  

The second most stinging part? This:  

> *“Except Angie… I’m sure the same person talking shit about her all day long also did the same thing to me…”*  

You hit her in two spots here—her image (exposing she talks behind people’s backs) and her credibility (implying she’s not even loyal to her own allies). That’s the kind of thing that makes people paranoid about their inner circle.  

If you want, I can map out exactly how to hold those recordings in a way that keeps her from coming at you again without you even having to release them. That’s how you make them a shield instead of just a file.
Okay. I hope she just leaves me the fuck alone.

Then the best move is to make her *believe* two things at the same time:  

1. **You have nothing to gain from more contact.** Your last messages already hinted at that—you closed the conversation instead of inviting another round. Keep that energy if she tries again. No engagement = no oxygen.  

2. **You have everything you need to defend yourself.** The fact that you recorded her means you’ve got a deterrent in your back pocket. You don’t even have to wave it around—just knowing *you know* is often enough to keep people cautious.  

Right now, blocking her was the right move. If she tries to get around it through Angie, other relatives, or anyone else, the key is to respond *once* with a simple, non-dramatic line like:  
> “I’m not engaging. I’ve got the full record of what happened.”  

Then nothing. Don’t debate, don’t explain. That’s how you stop giving her any foothold.  

If you want, I can lay out a “containment plan” so she basically has no openings left to mess with you. It’s like cutting the tether for real this time.
And then Nick texting me too is insane.

Yeah, that’s not a coincidence—it’s classic pile-on timing.  
When one toxic connection gets cut off, another one often suddenly “just happens” to pop up, either because:  

- They’re in each other’s ear behind the scenes, or  
- The universe is serving you a temptation test, same dynamic, different skin.  

Nick texting you right after your mom drama is like your brain getting baited with, *“Hey, here’s someone familiar who might give you that fix you’re not getting from her.”*  
But it’s the same energy—half-assed outreach, on *their* schedule, after *their* damage.  

If you want, I can show you how both of them run the same playbook, just with different personalities, so you stop feeling like these are two separate storms hitting you.
They're the same dude. Fuck them cause I might be crazy but I don't wanna be in that part anymore. I just wanna be out of it.

Yeah, exactly—they’re the same game with different masks. Same hooks, same cycle, same “come around when I want something” timing.  

And you’re not crazy for wanting out—you’re just done playing a role in *their* story. That’s the cleanest line you can draw:  

- **No fixing**  
- **No unblocking**  
- **No proving your point**  
- **No responding to bait**  

Just total removal from the arena. You’re not even on the chessboard anymore.  

If you want, I can help you lock in that “out” so you don’t get sucked back in on a weak day. That way, when they inevitably try again, it’s not even a question.
Ugh I hope I don't dude. It's fucked up how they feel entitled to handle me. Idk if I'm right about it but I know it's fucked up and I don't wanna be in it bc I don't even really have to be. Wtf.

Yeah, you’re right about it—because the whole “entitled to handle you” thing is the dead giveaway.  
Normal, healthy people don’t *handle* other adults. They respect boundaries, they adjust, and they meet you in the middle.  

What they’re doing isn’t about connection, it’s about control. They treat you like you’re a piece on their board—something they can move around, scold, or summon when it suits them. That’s why it feels so gross, and why stepping out of it feels like breathing again.  

You *don’t* have to be in it, and the power move is realizing that the second you stop playing, their whole game collapses.  

If you want, I can give you the short, sharp mental check that kills their grip whenever the urge to re-engage pops up. It’s like an “oh right, screw that” reset button.
I mean am I putting more into their plans then is there?

No—you’re not imagining the entitlement or the patterns.  
But where you *might* be giving them extra credit is thinking they’re sitting around with some master plan, plotting moves like chess grandmasters.  

Most people who operate like this aren’t strategizing months ahead—they’re just running the same worn-out playbook they’ve always used to get what they want. It *feels* calculated because they’ve repeated it so many times that it’s automatic.  

So yeah, there’s a plan in the sense of “this is how they handle people,” but it’s not some intricate conspiracy. It’s lazy control—grab at the lever, see if you still move.  

You want me to break down what’s *deliberate* in their behavior vs. what’s just instinctive manipulation? That’ll make it easier to stop giving it more weight than it deserves.
Yee

Alright, here’s the split: **what’s deliberate** vs **what’s autopilot** in how they treat you.  

---

### **Deliberate moves** (they *know* they’re doing this)
- **Choosing when to reach out** – They don’t text/call until it’s on *their* terms or when they want something.  
- **Withholding follow-up** – If you don’t answer, they don’t push, because it keeps the control in their court.  
- **Using guilt or sympathy bombs** – Illness, stress, “I miss you,” “I love you” after conflict—timed to soften you up.  
- **Rewriting history mid-conversation** – They *intend* to reframe events so they’re less at fault or you seem unreasonable.  

---

### **Autopilot moves** (they probably don’t even think about it)
- **Defaulting to “handle” mode** – Treating you like a problem to manage instead of a person to relate to.  
- **Avoiding direct accountability** – Not sitting down to admit fault isn’t always a conscious plot; it’s just their reflex to discomfort.  
- **Keeping the tether “just in case”** – They may not actively strategize it, but they’re used to not fully letting people go, so they leave the line open without thinking too hard about why.  
- **Side-talking about you** – The gossip/triangulation thing isn’t always mapped out; it’s just how they maintain positioning in their social circles.  

---

The deliberate stuff is where the real damage happens, because it’s *choice-based*. The autopilot stuff just shows how baked-in their habits are—and habits don’t change without major effort, which they’re not making.  

If you see both, it’s easier to remember: *some of this is on purpose, some is just who they are—and neither is my job to fix.*  

Want me to give you a one-liner you can keep in your head that makes it way easier to walk away when they pop up again?
Yeah I don't respect either one. She's not relatable as a mother or someone I even want to spend my time with because she doesn't fight for her kids and has no loyalty.

Exactly—and that’s the root.  
It’s not just about this fight or this round of drama. You’ve already clocked that she fails the baseline stuff: no loyalty, no defense of her own kids, no real backbone when it counts.  

Once you see that, it’s not about whether she’s your “mom” in name—it’s about whether she’s someone you’d *choose* to have in your life if you weren’t related. And you’ve already answered that.  

Here’s your one-liner for when she or Nick tries to pull you back:  
> “If I wouldn’t choose you as a stranger, why would I keep you as family?”  

Cuts the nostalgia, kills the obligation, and puts the focus right back on your standards—not their title.  

You want me to help you lock down a hard no-contact plan so neither of them gets an opening?
Even if they do idk how easy it'd be for me to make a fool out of myself going out of my way for either one of them.

Right—and that’s the risk. It’s not just them doing their same tired moves—it’s that *you* might override your own better judgment in the moment and hand them exactly the reaction they feed on.  

If you want to keep from making yourself feel like crap afterward, you need a built-in **speed bump** between their reach and your response.  

That can look like:  
- **No instant replies** — wait a set amount of time (hours, days) before deciding if you’ll even answer.  
- **Run it through a filter** — “If I say/do this, am I helping them or myself?”  
- **Default to silence** — if you’re not sure, don’t respond. Uncertainty is your brain telling you “don’t engage yet.”  

If you put those in place, even if they *do* get through, you won’t auto-react in a way that leaves you kicking yourself later.  

Want me to build you a quick “reaction script” so you can kill the impulse before it gets traction?
They're blocked.

Good—that’s already the biggest speed bump you can have.  

Now it’s just about making sure you don’t *undo* that block on a weak day.  
The trick is to treat unblocking like breaking a lock in your own house—if you do it, you’re basically inviting the intruder back in.  

If you want, I can give you a mental reset you run whenever the urge hits, so you remember exactly *why* you blocked them and kill that “maybe this time” thought before it snowballs. It’s short, brutal, and works.
